summary.p: There is hardly enough time to confirm the receipt of his letter; regarding the situation in which the Emperor [Charles V] finds himself, he has again been informed of what he has already communicated; in Germany, measures against the Turk [Suleiman I] are indeed being discussed, but there is no talk of moral improvement. In Myconius’ house, a son of Fridolin Ryff has fallen victim to the plague. He can only thank Bullinger for his efforts. A Basel resident met Christian [Wirth] and Konrad [Suter] in Augsburg, who were supposedly on their way to Tübingen. He wants to help the widow recommended by Bullinger. Greetings.

div.p: Greetings. There is hardly enough time to confirm the receipt of your letter. Regarding the Emperor, I have again received the information I recently communicated. It is still uncertain whether he has been captured or besieged. Frequent consultations are taking place throughout Germany against the Turk; there is no talk of moral improvement.
The plague is still raging. Tomorrow will be the eighth day since a young man of good hope, the son of Fridolin Ryff, a senator, was carried out of my house. I await what more God wills.
You undertake labors to gratify me, for which I give you immortal thanks; for what else can I do unless the Lord offers an opportunity sometime?
A certain resident of Basel was in Augsburg a few days ago; he reported that he saw and greeted Christian and Konrad there, and that they said they were going straight to Tübingen. This is for you.
For the widow you commend to me, I will be most ready to bestow whatever good I can, in your name.
I have nothing more, nor can I do more.
Farewell with your wife and children, with Theodor, Pellican, and others in the Lord. Pray, I ask, to the Lord for us.
To Lord Heinrich Bullinger, Antistes of Zurich, his brother in the Lord, to be respected.
